moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. c3 Nf6: Rather than form an ideal center by recapturing the Pawn, White presses forward.
moves.6... d5: The Cardinal, naturally, prefers a Bishop to a Knight.
moves.7. exf6 dxc4: Now it is in fact *Black* who has a strong Pawn center.
moves.8. Qe2+ Be6 9. fxg7 Rg8: Aiming, after capturing the obstructing Pawn, at the future home of the White King.
moves.13... Rxg7: Black has four pieces now trained on the denuded White K-side.
moves.14. Qb5+: Removing the Q from the defense of the imperiled K-side.
moves.15. Qxb7: ...which White falls into. Now the Q is cut off entirely from the scene of action.
moves.16. Kxg2: The King is now exposed to the fury of the Cardinal's pieces.
moves.17... Bd5+: Excellent utilization of a Bishop by the Cardinal.
